node.title: Austria to reimpose national lockdown, make vaccines mandatory as COVID-19 cases surge
node.alt: Police officers check the vaccination status of shoppers in Vienna, Austria.
node.description: The lockdown, starting on Monday, will be the first in western Europe this autumn as a fourth wave drives case numbers upwards across the continent.
node.content: ["Austria will enter a full national lockdown and make vaccines mandatory by February next year after setting a daily record of new COVID-19 case numbers.\u00a0", "The lockdown, starting on Monday, will be the first in western Europe this autumn as a fourth wave drives case numbers upwards across the continent.", "Austria has one of the highest infection rates in Europe, recording an incidence of 991 per 100,000 people over the past seven days.", "The country also has some of the lowest vaccinations rates in western Europe \u2013 at around 65 per cent of the population \u2013 and on Monday authorities had imposed a lockdown on unvaccinated people, preventing nearly 2 million people the age of 12 from leaving home unless for essential activities.", "\"We have not succeeded in convincing enough people to get vaccinated,\" Chancellor Alexander Schallenberg told a news conference on Friday.", "\"It hurts that such measures still have to be taken.", "\"We do not want a fifth wave \u2013 nor do we want a sixth or seventh wave\".", "The lockdown will see non-essential shops close, people told to work from home and schools will remain open for children of essential workers or with specific learning needs.", "The lockdown is set to last 20 days from Monday until December 12, but will be reassessed after 10 days.", "The requirement for people to get vaccines will begin on February 1, although it was not clear immediately how it will be enforced.", "Austria's Health Minister Wolfgang Muckstein said the lockdown would not be enough on its own to break \"vicious circle\".", "Other European nations, including Germany, are also considering new restrictions as cases surge due to a combination of colder weather and low vaccination numbers.", "More to come."]
